Hi, my name is Yuna Kim.\nDo you want to listen to my story?
Leave your love message for Yuna.\nLet\'s make Yuna smile now! :)
Pictures may show up VERY slowly under slow network conditions.
Yuna was born in Bucheon City on September 5th, 1990.

Yuna began skating at 5.\nHer coach at the time, Jong-Hyeon Ryu, strongly suggested to her mother that Yuna should continue to skate, predicting that she would become a world-class figure skater in the future.
At age 10, Yuna finished five major triple jumps. From 2002, she won several novice titles at international competitions while continuing her reign as the Korean champion in 2004.

Yuna won 2005-06 Junior Grand Prix Final, where she landed seven triple jumps, including a triple flip â€“ triple toe loop combination and a double axel â€“ triple toe loop combination during her free skate.
After securing her fourth senior national title, she won the gold medal scoring 177.54 points overall at the 2006 World Junior Championships.
Yuna entered the senior level in 2006-07 season.

Yuna made her senior debut at Skate Canada by winning a bronze medal. After winning a gold medal at TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard, she amazed the world again by winning the Grand Prix Final with 184.20 points.
And... Yuna headed to Tokyo for the Worlds.

The world witnessed Yuna\'s excellent skating skills and artistic expressions through her record breaking short program, El Tango de Roxanne. It was a signal of Queen Yuna\'s era in the figure skating world.
She was the first female figure skater to receive a GOE of 2.00+ on every jump component. Also, she was the only skater to successfully perform all triple combination jumps in on season.
Yuna started the 2007-08 season winning the 2007 Cup of China

At the Cup of Russia, Yuna won both the short program scoring 63.50 points and the free skate with 133.70 points, to finish first overall with 197.20 points, which set a world record for the free skate score under the ISU Judging System.

Yuna qualified for the Grand Prix Final in Turin, Italy. She won the short program and was placed second in the free skate. With a total score of 196.83 points, she won her second Grand Prix Final to become the third female skater to win two GPFs in a row, and to win all Grand Prix competitions in the same season.
With persistent hip injury and back pain, she competed at the Worlds where she won her consecutive bronze medal by rebounding in the free skate to win the program with gorgeous Miss Saigon.
Yuna was placed first at Skate America and Cup of China with her spectacular programs, Danse Macabre and Scheherazade.
After winning a silver medal at Grand Prix Final in Korea, she won another gold medal in Four Continents in Vancouver with a new world record in the short program.
During the 2009 Worlds in LA, Yuna set another new world record in the short program. She also won the free program showing great presentation skills with her artistry and musicality.
As a result, she set a new world record total of 207.71 as well as winning her first World Championship title and she became the first female skater to surpass 200 points.
2009-10, the season of the Olympic Games has come.
Yuna surprised everyone by choosing 007 James Bond Medley as her short program and Concerto in F by George Gershwin for her free program.

Yuna won a gold medal at the TrophÃ©e Eric Bompard by setting a new world record for the free skate and the overall score. Then, she won again at the Skate America by setting a new world record for the short program.
In February 2010, Yuna\'s long awaited day finally came...
On February 23, Yuna amazed the world by her magnificent clean short program with a record breaking 78.50.
Two days later, Yuna executed another perfect skating in her free program with a new record of 150.06.

Overall, Yuna totaled 228.56 points, shattering her personal best and own old world record by a margin of 18 points. She won the gold medal, becoming the first South Korean skater to medal in any discipline of figure skating at the Olympic Games.
2010 Vancouver Olympics was not just a dream come true for Yuna, but great inspiration for all. Her Olympic performance was praised by legendary skaters and media.
After winning a silver medal at Worlds, Yuna attended various off-ice events and continued her study.
Also, she hosted a couple of huge ice shows in Korea and LA participated by Olympic medalists.

After making a tough decision to come back to ice, Yuna chose not to compete in the Grand Prix series to focus on the 2011 World Championships. At that time, she was training in LA with her new coach, Peter Oppegard.
At the 2011 Worlds, Yuna won the first place in the short program with her artistically expressed Giselle.
Yuna beautifully skated to another masterpiece free program, Homage to Korea, which included Korean folk music, Arirang.
After the season 2010-11, Yuna actively fulfilled her role as Korean delegation by promoting PyeongChang as an athlete ambassador and an Olympic champion.
She was one of the eight Korean delegates who appeared before the July 6 IOC conference and delivered a presentation for Pyeongchang, which won the hosting rights over other rival cities.

In May 2011, Yuna began to host a TV program called Kim Yuna\'s Kiss and Cry. The program portrayed the challenging process of ten popular entertainers as they learned how to figure skate from professional skaters.
On July 2012, Yuna made an announcement

that she would skate competitively in the 2012-13 season, with the ultimate goal of skating in the 2014 Winter Olympics. Yuna started training with her childhood coaches Shin Hye-sook and Ryu Jong-hyeon.

To earn the minimum score required for Championship events, Yuna skated in the NRW Trophy in Germany, where she won the first place with new beautifully choreographed programs, the Kiss of the Vampire and Les MisÃ©rables.
In January 2013, Yuna competed in the Korean Championships to pick herself a spot for the Worlds, and she placed the first by showing masterpieces to her home fans.
With two victories, Yuna headed to London, Canada for the Worlds.
As usual, Yuna\'s short program was spectacular enough to place her in the first place. Her jumps were huge and solid and her artistic presentation skills were fantastic.

She also won the free skate after executing a clean long program and earning 148.34 points. Her technical score of 74.73 and her presentation of 73.61 were both the highest of the night, and she was also the only skater of the competition to get tens in her program components.

Totaling 218.31 points overall Yuna claimed her second world title, surpassing the rest of the competitors by 20.42 points, which was the largest difference between gold and silver in the nine years the ISU Judging System had been used in the World Championships.
2013-14, the last competitive season for Yuna began.
For the Olympic season, Yuna chose Send in the Clowns as her short program and AdiÃ³s Nonino for her free program.
After skipping the Grand Prix events due to an injury, Yuna competed in Golden Spin of Zagreb in Croatia where she placed first. Then she won another gold medal in the Korean Championships.
Yuna placed first after flawlessly performing her beautiful short program. Having to skate early in the competition was not a problem at all for Yuna.
The next day, Yuna performed another gorgeous free program which deserves a gold medal. Regardless of the color of the medal, Yuna\'s free program performance was the best of all that night.
Although Sochi Olympics marked the end of her competitive skating career, she left a great legacy no one ever can do.

Yuna is the first South Korean figure skater to win a medal at an ISU Junior or Senior Grand Prix event, ISU Championship, and the Olympic Games. She is the first female skater to win the Olympic Games, the World Championships, the Four Continents Championships and the Grand Prix Final.

She is the current record holder for ladies in the free skating and the combined total under the ISU Judging System. She has broken world record scores 11 times under the ISU Judging System since 2007, eight of which being records she herself set.

She is also the first female skater to surpass the 140-point and 150-point free skating mark and the 200-point total mark under the ISU Judging System. Throughout her entire career, Yuna had never finished a competition off the podium.
A lot of junior skaters in Korea are now following the footsteps of Yuna who opened the door of opportunity for her juniors.
Off the ice, Yuna has been participating in a lot of humanitarian activities as UNICEF Goodwill Ambassador.
